title: How much do rappers make? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, there's some good news and there's some bad news. The good news is that if there has ever been a time to make money from being a rapper, then this is definitely the time. The bad news is that the odds are still stacked heavily against you if you want to become the next big thing in Hip Hop. If we go back just 15 years, then making a living from being a rapper was a totally different ball game. All your music would be burnt onto CD and you would only make your money from hand-to-hand sales, walking round your local town and selling your CD to people in your neighbourhood. If you wanted to get bigger than that then you would have to post your CD to record labels and hope that an agent somewhere saw potential in your music. You may get some money from a gig here and there if you were lucky and if you wanted promotion then you’d have to get a gig in a big city, maybe at a rap battle event. But keep in mind that Hip Hop had only really gone mainstream in the U.S so if you lived anywhere else in the world, this was even further out of your grasp. But things have changed. Fast forward to 2018, with the internet now becoming the main platform for artists to promote and sell their music, the possibility of making money has dramatically improved. With websites like Spofity and YouTube anyone can upload their music and videos for the entire world to view or listen, with potential to make capital from sales and views. And then with social media like Facebook and Twitter, you can promote your music and create a fanbase much easier as well. Mechandise is now much cheaper and accessible to produce and sell, and getting gigs and applying for positions in rap events is also easier than ever. If you also keep in mind that Hip Hop has now arguably become the most popular genre of music worldwide, this means that making a living from Hip Hop is definitely much more possible than it has been in previous years. But this doesn’t mean that it’s going to be easy, because having all of these perks comes at a cost: much more competition. It seems that these days, every man and their dog considers themselves a ‘rapper’, meaning that you really do need to be on top of your game: considering every last detail of how you write, record and promote your music.. and yourself. You need to consider the whole package, rather than just the music. Here are the five main factors that a rapper will need to keep in mind if he wants to make any decent amount of money: Beats - you can’t just get away with using any beat. Ideally you need to have your own beats so that you can’t get done for copyright when you upload them and also when you perform the music, you have high quality WAV beats and not some MP3 ripped off of YouTube. This may require some investement buying beats from producers or time spent learning how to make beats yourself.Social Media - you’re going to probably have to run all of this by yourself, and make sure you’re updating it as often as possible to keep people interested. You’ll also have to be careful about what you say and how you say it, because people are going to be watching your every move, looking for something that they can witch hunt you with if you put a foot out of place.Appearance - because there is more focus on musicians appearance now more than there ever has been, you will need to make sure you ‘look the part’ or at least that you have some sort of ‘look’ that people will recognise you for. This shouldn’t really be something for a musician to have to worry about, but unfortunately in this day and age, it is.Visuals - as with appearance, the same applies to your videos. People now expect you to have videos or ‘bar videos’ which will need to have something about them in order to get shares and likes. Keep in mind this is all going to cost some money, so you’ll be definitely having to invest some of your own cash before you’ve seen any sufficient amount of return for your capital.Material - your material will have to be original. There will have to be something about it. Whether it be the rhymes, the flow, the delivery, the content… or whatever. One of these things or a combination of these things will need to stand out from the rest. Try to avoid emulating what other people are doing and aim to add something new to the genre.So as you can probably tell from these 5 factors, it’s not only going to involve maybe making some investment at first but it’s also going to involve a lot of hard work if you’re going to be taking it seriously. So yes, making a living from being a rapper is possible and more possible than it’s ever been. But it’s also very likely going to be a full-time job. If you’re already working a job then you’re going to be having a lot of late nights and early mornings with not many days off, and if you’re unemployed then you will need to get working towards your goals asap to start getting some money in. Once you’ve laid down the foundations of your business you can start trying to get some gigs which can bring in some revenue. And once you have a decent sized fan base maybe get some merchandise to see how it sells. You can also apply for rap battles if this is your thing as it is a great platform for promotion, probably the best in the industry. But remember that rap battles can make rappers, but also destroy them. So you’ll have to be careful about what people can find out about you and make sure you're good at battling as its completely different from just rapping. This should be all you need to get started and hopefully you will be able to fulfill your dream of making a living from rap. But if it doesn’t work out, then don’t let that stop you from making music and being a rapper. Rap shouldn’t be about making money, it should be about enjoying making music. Make sure that you’re enjoying what you’re doing, and then if you make some money, well then that’s just an added bonus. Good luck.
